title: 106_hr1184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Earthquake Hazards Reduction Authorization Act of 1999" and authorizes appropriations. The Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 is amended to allocate specific funding amounts for FEMA and the United States Geological Survey for fiscal years 2000 and 2001. The Director's responsibilities under the Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 include allocating $46,100,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $47,500,000 for fiscal year 2001. Specific amounts are designated for the Global Seismic Network and the Scientific Earthquake Studies Advisory Committee. Amendments include adjustments to paragraph formatting and punctuation. The Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 is amended to allocate specific amounts for fiscal years 2000 and 2001, including $9,000,000 for 2000 and $9,500,000 for 2001. The National Science Foundation is also allocated $1,600,000 for 2000 and $1,650,000 for 2001, along with $19,000,000 for engineering research and $10,900,000 for other purposes. The Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 is amended to allocate specific amounts for fiscal years 2000 and 2001, including $19,000,000 for engineering research and $10,900,000 for geosciences research in 2000, and $19,600,000 for engineering research and $11,200,000 for geosciences research in 2001. The National Institute of Standards and Technology is also allocated $2,200,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $2,265,000 for fiscal year 2001. SEC. 3. REPEALS.

Section 10 and subsections (e) and (f) of section 12 of the Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 are repealed.

SEC. 4. ADVANCED NATIONAL SEISMIC RESEARCH AND MONITORING SYSTEM.

The Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 is amended to include a new section for the Advanced National Seismic Research and Monitoring System. The Director of the US Geological Survey will establish an Advanced National Seismic Research and Monitoring System to enhance earthquake research and warning capabilities. Within 120 days of the Earthquake Hazards Reduction Authorization Act of 1999, a 5-year management plan will be submitted to Congress for the system's operation. The Director of the US Geological Survey will establish the Advanced National Seismic Research and Monitoring System with annual cost estimates for modernization and operation, milestones, standards, and performance goals. Authorization of appropriations includes $33,500,000 for fiscal year 2000 and $33,700,000 for fiscal year 2001. The Advanced National Seismic Research and Monitoring System will receive funding as follows: $33,700,000 for fiscal year 2001, $35,100,000 for fiscal year 2002, $35,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, and $33,500,000 for fiscal year 2004. Additionally, $4,500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000 and $10,300,000 for fiscal year 2001 for operational purposes. The Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 is amended to include a new section for the Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation. The Director of the National Science Foundation will establish a Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation to upgrade experimental facilities for testing structures and models. $7,700,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000. The National Science Foundation is allocated $7,700,000 for the Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation in fiscal year 2000. Additional funding amounts are authorized for the following years: $28,200,000 for 2001, $24,400,000 for 2002, $4,500,000 for 2003, and $17,000,000 for 2004. Scientific Earthquake Studies Advisory Committee established. The Director of the US Geological Survey establishes a Scientific Earthquake Studies Advisory Committee. The committee consists of up to ten qualified individuals selected based on distinguished service records, representing a variety of views and expertise. Recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences and other organizations are considered in the selection process. The Advisory Committee advises the Director on the US Geological Survey's role in the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program, issues an annual report to Congress, and addresses policy matters affecting the program. SEC. 7. BUDGET COORDINATION. Section 5 of the Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act of 1977 is amended to include budget coordination guidance for Program agencies in preparing annual appropriations requests. Program agencies must submit an annual budget to the Office of Management and Budget, including reports detailing proposed activities, their contributions to the Program, and the allocation of appropriations to each activity. SEC. 8. REPORT ON AT-RISK POPULATIONS. The Director of FEMA must submit a report to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment, detailing how the Program addresses the needs of at-risk populations like the elderly, disabled, non-English speakers, single-parent households, and the poor. The report should suggest additional actions and legislative authority if needed. SEC. 9. PUBLIC ACCESS TO EARTHQUAKE INFORMATION. Amends the Earthquake Hazards Reduction Act to increase public access to earthquake information. 

SEC. 10. LIFELINES. Amends the Act to include infrastructure in the definition of lifelines.

SEC. 11. COMPLIANCE WITH BUY AMERICAN ACT. Entities must comply with the Buy American Act when expending funds authorized by this Act.

SEC. 12. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS; REQUIREMENT REGARDING NOTICE. SEC. 12. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS; REQUIREMENT REGARDING NOTICE. Entities receiving financial assistance under this Act should purchase American-made equipment and products. The Secretary of Transportation must provide a notice to recipients of the assistance about this requirement. SEC. 13. PROHIBITION OF CONTRACTS. If a court or Federal agency determines that a person falsely labeled a product as "Made in America," they will be ineligible for any contracts funded by this Act. Passed the House of Representatives on April 21, 1999.
